Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: I glanced at the clock on my computer screen, watching the minutes tick by. The call volume was unusually light today, and my supervisor had just sent a message: “Feel free to take your break whenever you need.” Normally, I’d stick to my scheduled time, but today was different. My church was holding a special midweek service, and I’d promised to help set up. As a Christian, I felt a deep responsibility to be present, to worship, and to serve my community. But as a telemarketer, I was expected to respect my work hours, even if the rules were relaxed today. My heart tugged me toward the church, but my mind reminded me of my commitment to my job. I stared at the “Log Out” button, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me, each demanding my loyalty. The tension built inside me, a silent battle between my faith and my work ethic, and I sat frozen, unable to choose.
